verbs.description: preempt (third-person singular simple present preempts, present participle preempting, simple past and past participle preempted)

examples: He preempted that hill to be its king.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To displace or take the place of (by having higher precedence, etc).
examples: Floppy disks were preempted by CDs.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To prevent or beat to the punch, to forestall an expected occurrence by acting first.
examples: [â€¦]  the knife when he passed it, managing to pull it from the doorframe, but Riverwind preempted his action and slammed the pistol-butt down on his wrist.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To secure (land, etc.) by the right of preemption (purchasing before others, e.g. land because one already occupies it).
(bridge, intransitive) To make a preemptive bid at bridge.
